items.title: Do we still use or advertise examples/environment.yml?
items.body: Seems not used and out of date, and the docs say to install a holoviz package (into a dedicated env). So shall we remove examples/environment.yml?

items.title: In Plotting.ipynb indicies should be replaced with index
items.body:
Holoviz:  0.11.3
HoloViews:  1.13.2

#### My Pain

In Plotting.ipynb Exercise-3 the proposed Solution below does not work

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42288570/83405801-a059ef00-a40d-11ea-8e6c-ea3ecd3564b6.png)

```bash
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-42-1db9b4e4b0c2> in <module>
     11     return hv.Overlay(circles)
     12 
---> 13 circle_marker = hv.DynamicMap(circles_callback, streams=[selection_stream])

~\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\envs\holoviz-tutorial\lib\site-packages\holoviews\core\spaces.py in __init__(self, callback, initial_items, streams, **params)
    907         self._posarg_keys = util.validate_dynamic_argspec(self.callback,
    908                                                           self.kdims,
--> 909                                                           self.streams)
    910         # Set source to self if not already specified
    911         for stream in self.streams:

~\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\envs\holoviz-tutorial\lib\site-packages\holoviews\core\util.py in validate_dynamic_argspec(callback, kdims, streams)
    435             raise KeyError('Callable {name!r} missing keywords to '
    436                            'accept stream parameters: {unassigned}'.format(name=name,
--> 437                                                                     unassigned=unassigned))
    438 
    439 

KeyError: "Callable 'circles_callback' missing keywords to accept stream parameters: index"
```

#### Solution

change `indicies` to `index`. That works.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42288570/83405889-c8e1e900-a40d-11ea-86c1-a237e31892fa.png)

items.title: pn.interact not stretching
items.body:
Holoviz 0.11.3

#### My Pain

I would like to show to fellow Pythonistas how awesome Holoviz and Panel is. But this example does not look nice

02_Building_Panels.ipynb

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42288570/83386920-1fd6c680-a3ec-11ea-9ac1-7e5a2fe27841.png)

#### Workaround

`pn.config.sizing_mode="stretch_width"`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42288570/83387056-5f051780-a3ec-11ea-8774-949d4848583e.png)

```python
pn.config.sizing_mode="stretch_width"

def select_row(row=0):
    return df.loc[row].compute()

pn.interact(select_row, row=(0, len(df)-1), width=10)
```

items.title: Formatting issue with DataFrame's long time stamps
items.body: #### ALL software version info (this library, plus any other relevant software, e.g. bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, etc) panel: 0.9.3 holoviews: 1.13.1 pandas: 1.0.3 Browser: Chrome 80.0 on macOS 10.14.6 #### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior Following the Holoviz tutorial, I saw nicely right-hand formatted long time strings, but that doesn't happen here. This has obviously something to do with pandas new timezone management, but I haven't learned yet how to influence the display of times properly since that change. #### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue ``` import dask.dataframe as dd import panel as pn df = dd.read_parq uet('../data/earthquakes.parq', columns=['time', 'place', 'mag']).reset_index(drop=True).persist() pn.pane.DataFrame(df.head()) ``` #### Screenshots or screencasts of the bug in action while in the tutorial things looked like this:

items.title: Broken Links on Web Site (Background Page)
items.body:
#### ALL software version info
Web Site as Accessed on 7th of March 2020

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
Links on https://holoviz.org/background.html in the Demos section expected to work - result in 404 error.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue

```
from requests_html import HTMLSession
sess = HTMLSession()
base_url = "https://holoviz.org/background.html"
# Get the response from the base URL
resp = sess.get(base_url)
# Get the links
links = resp.html.links
# At the moment we are only interested in absolute/external links
full_links = [l for l in links if l.startswith('http')]

broken = [] # Storage for broken links
for l in full_links: # Check each in turn
    print(f"Checking {l}")
    try:
        link_resp = sess.get(l)
    except Exception as e: # Very bad Links
        print(f"Failed to get {l} - {e}")
        broken.append(l)
    if not link_resp.ok or link_resp.status_code != 200:  # i.e Bad Lnks
        broken.append(l)
print('Broken:', broken)
```

items.title: [help wanted] how to created sanky-like hover effect for box/polygons
items.body:
I love the hover effect demonstrated in reference/elements/bokeh/Sankey.ipynb, with values in text and ROI shaded. 
Is it possible to make similar effect for box/polygons?
Furthermore, is it possible to have attributes associated to each box/polygons just for hover message visualization?

items.title: Rename github org from pyviz to holoviz
items.body: I was talking about with matplotlib folks at PyData and they were saying that they'd like for holoviz projects to have their own github org so that the growing number of truly collaborative projects (https://github.com/pyviz/website, https://github.com/pyviz/spec, https://github.com/pyviz/contrib_colormaps) appear more as separate from the holoviz libraries. I took a look at [renaming github orgs](https://help.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-organizations-and-teams/renaming-an-organization) and it doesn't seem too hard, so it might be reasonable to rename the pyviz organization to holoviz, and then to quickly move those three repos back to pyviz. That really doesn't seem like it'd be too rough and the links would redirect, so it wouldn't break anyone.

items.title: Make edited hv.Table values overwrite values in the source dataframe
items.body:
Hi 
I am trying to make efficient use of holoviews to edit some data. I had a look at one example in http://holoviews.org/reference/streams/bokeh/BoundsX.html#bokeh-gallery-boundsx

I did the changes marked in **bold** in order to show all the table rows (commenting the describe()..) for the corresponding points selected and added editable=True in the options builder. What I really want is to be able to edit the table values in the hv.Table and write these edits back to df with edits stored. I would be really interested in this ability to store information back through holoviews.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import holoviews as hv
from holoviews import streams
hv.extension('bokeh')

n=200
xs = np.linspace(0, 1, n)
ys = np.cumsum(np.random.randn(n))
df = pd.DataFrame({'x': xs, 'y': ys})
curve = hv.Curve(df)

def make_from_boundsx(boundsx):
    sub = df.set_index('x').loc[boundsx[0]:boundsx[1]]
    return hv.Table(sub)**.opts(editable=True)  # .describe().reset_index().values, 'stat', 'value')**

dmap = hv.DynamicMap(make_from_boundsx, streams=[streams.BoundsX(source=curve, boundsx=(0,0))])

curve.opts(tools=['xbox_select']) + dmap

items.title: Unable to access data array inside gv.WMTS tiles
items.body:
@jsignell @ocefpaf

Working from a notebook...

```
import geoviews as gv
import holoviews as hv
hv.extension('bokeh')

lon = -121.8144
lat = 48.7767
dx  = dy = 0.01
url   = 'https://mt1.google.com/vt/lyrs=s&x={X}&y={Y}&z={Z}'

extents = (lon-dx, lat-dy, lon+dx, lat+dy)
tiles = gv.WMTS(url, extents=extents)
tiles
```

I'm trying to get access to the data array and coordinates inside the tiles object so that I can save it to geotif. Not sure if support for this is just built in so my plan was to pull out the data array and save it using rasterio, as suggested here https://github.com/pyviz/geoviews/issues/68.

Not seeing a method that lets me access the array. Maybe there is a hidden one that can be exposed?

items.title: SciPy 2019 tutorial plan
items.body:
This issue collects to-do items and planning for the SciPy 2019 tutorials, subsuming previous such issues #42, #90, and #97. Bigger tasks we expect to do before the tutorial:

- [x] Introduction 01 should be replaced with a short demo (10-15min) (e.g. datashader 1billion dashboard, gapminders, nb with other types of plots) [#188]
- [x] Move Introduction 01 out of the tutorial itself, to be next to background nb as an overview (jsignell) [#188]
- [x] Reduce total amount of material expected to be covered


NEW WRITING:
- [x] Boost focus on Panel
- [ ] Boost coverage of libraries other than Bokeh
- [x] More/better/more-hands-on exercises
- [x] Reduce overlap between tutorial sections
- [x] Try to make the difference between holoviews and hvplot more explicit in the text.
- [ ] Review feedback from prior tutorials (incorporated below)
    * [ ] Add list of references and weblinks for further exploration
    * [ ] Have a list of conference presentations coming up that use these tools (@jbednar)
    * [ ] Explain what these packages will _not_ do (@jbednar)
    * [ ] How do other tools fit in? Seaborn, ggpy, etc.  (@jbednar)
    * [x] Early examples were basic, then later ones quickly became impenetrable, so that we could only see what CAN be done, not HOW to do it.  Try to balance better.


ENV MANAGEMENT:
- [x] Move topics from datashader and holoviews sites into pyviz, as most combine multiple tools and make good launching-off points. (jsignell)
- [x] Streamline conda environment instructions/setup: (jsignell)
    * [x] Only install holoviews and not geoviews
    * [x] Remove conda-forge from list of channels
    * [x] Update pinning, if needed
    * [x] Measure the time to build the conda environment, and see if it can be improved if not reasonable
    * [ ] Test conda install on Windows
    * [x] Make sure everything is pip-installable as well as conda-installable (#81) (but warn pip users that they are on their own)

Other to-do items we hope to be able to get to as well:

- [x] Remove numbers from the website versions of notebooks, leaving them in the .ipynb files to show ordering (jsignell)
- [x] Remove ! and > characters in the prompts in the installation instructions; Windows users (in particular) were copy-pasting this into their command prompt (jsignell)
- [ ] Provide a binder or similar environment that users can use if their environment doesn't work (https://github.com/pyviz/pyviz/issues/98)
- [ ] Separate suggested diversions/more detail more clearly from what to do next in the tutorial.
- [x] Add multiple plotting libraries to the first tutorial sections
- [ ] How to handle matplotlib inline and discuss it
- [x] Make sure data isn't redownloaded when updating, when following our instructions
- [ ] Merge in content from the PyData Cookbook (Jim; https://github.com/pydata/pydata-cookbook/pull/26)
- [ ] Change 08_Custom_Interactivity.ipynb to use new RangeSelect tool
- [x] Mention new Links feature that will allow custom interactivity without needing a live server
- [x] Introduce DynamicMap and HoloMap properly
- [x] 09_Operations_and_Pipelines.ipynb starts using datashader without introducing it/why to use it/that it will be described in the next section?
- [x] Tighten up descriptions -- Q: is the whole thing a tutorial, or is each notebook a tutorial? A: Each nb is a section
- [x] Reduce overlap with holoviews.org, primarily just pointing people from pyviz.org to holoviews.org
- [x] Should fold in tutorial A1's material somewhere; it's odd to have it in an appendix. It made sense when the tutorial was smaller, but now that there is always more material than can be covered, it's confusing to have it separate, so that the other material can't tell whether these concepts have been introduced.

Seemingly unrelated tasks mentioned in previous issues, collected here to avoid forgetting them:

- [ ] Add a section to pyviz.org with links to maintainer-focused projects (nbsite, nbval, nbsmoke, autover, etc.)
- [ ] Make pyviz tests cover installing as a package and other new functionality (#81)
- [ ] Add twitter feed listening to multiple projects
- [ ] Need automated scripts for making at least the first pass at the site logo and favicon bitmaps from a transparent SVG source; currently edited those by hand for pyviz.org and other project sites have non-transparent logos. (See pyviz/nbsite#40)

items.title: PyViz topics - where should they live
items.body:
I am opening this issue to capture various ideas of where and how to store in-depth examples that span pyviz projects and possibly involve larger datasets. We call these types of examples "topics". 

## Current state of pyviz-topics GH org
We have created a "pyviz-topics" GH org to handle these types of things. So far that org has 3 repos: 
 - [EarthML](https://github.com/pyviz-topics/earthml) and [EarthSim](https://github.com/pyviz-topics/earthsim) are essentially websites with specific environments, and tutorials and topics that relate roughly to machine learning and simulations in the Earth Science context
 - [contrib](https://github.com/pyviz-topics/contrib) is intended as a location where users can submit examples with a low barrier to entry. These examples are not necessarily expected to be polished or maintained.

## pyviz-demos
There is another GH org called [pyviz-demos](https://github.com/pyviz-demos) that takes a different, very binder-driven, approach. That organization contains a repo for each example (a repo can be as little as a notebook and config files).

# Proposals
I am going to write down every idea that I can think of for how to keep track of the examples.

## Each repo is an example (like pyviz-demos)
This is **my preferred approach**. I think it will serve us best in the long-run and make it easy to pull examples for use in tutorials and talks. This matches most closely the current pattern of just throwing independent notebooks up on anaconda.org. And it would hopefully help prevent duplication. I think for this to work we'd need a good template repo.

PROS:
 - Flat hierarchy might make examples more discoverable, especially when paired with a gallery page that shows thumbnails of them.
 - Works well with binder.
 - Ensures environment isolation.
 - If there are particular updates that an example needs, those issues can be made right on the repo for the example. 
 - If example is already a repo - this will be a very easy move. 
 - Good for talks that use one example. Just point to the one repo. User doesn't need to know about the others. 
 - Could use labels to filter which projects use panel, or something

CONS:
 - Flat hierarchy might make examples less discoverable since they aren't grouped by content.
 - Lots of overhead with config files.
 - Hard to do something with all the repos.
 - We already have 3 repos in there that don't match this pattern. Are they just exceptions?

## Subject area repos with examples sorted
As a start, we could capture all the topics at datashader topics by adding "politcs", "networks",  "geo" (might be able to use symbolic links to link census in both geo and politics). 

PROS:
 - Similar to what we already have going with EarthML and EarthSim.
 - Might improve discoverability if people come in knowing that they want astro examples or something. 
 - Will highlight what pyviz is proven to be good at (nd earth science data probably, also points on a map)
 - Could make some nice discipline-specific sites that might lure people in.

CONS:
 - Hard to sort examples into content areas (eg is census "politics" or "geo"?)
 - Will highlight gaps in the types of long-form examples that we've written for pyviz and possibly make it look like pyviz isn't good at these things even if it might be (BI probably)
 - There are multiple axes on which we might want to sort examples. I could imagine someone saying I just want to see an example that uses panel and hvplot (but maybe that isn't supposed to be a topic).
 - Can't be binderized as easily

## One new repo with all the examples in it

Within that repo there would be top level config files, and then directories where each directory corresponds to one example. Inside each of these there would be an environment.yml, possibly a catalog.yml if intake is being used, and at least one notebook.

PROS:
 - Less overhead with duplicated config files. 
 - Could make it into one website using gh-pages.

CONS:
 - Environment isolation isn't as strict.
 - Meaningless nesting.
 - Harder for new users to discover just the example that they are interested in. 
 - Can't be binderized as easily

## Related issues
 - The migration from datashader to pyviz (#84). 
 - Topics should indicate what they demonstrate (#85)
 - Users should be able to contribute (#147)

items.title: Centralized location for easy pyviz contributions
items.body:
One of the most difficult things when authoring documentation is coming up with good, simple examples. This is a problem when trying to author tutorial material, user guides, gallery examples and so on.

Currently we have no good, consistent way for pyviz users to share demos and examples with each other. For instance, @philippjfr and @jbednar use anaconda.org accounts to share notebooks, some of our users have little github repos for pyviz examples, some use gists and nbviewer for that etc.

I would really like to have a centralized location where all pyviz users can share various ideas and examples of what is possible with these tools. 

This idea isn't new, I had hoped [holoviews-contrib](https://github.com/ioam/holoviews-contrib) could fulfill this role but unfortunately that repo never took off. The goal of this issue is to brainstorm ways to make this idea work.

Here are some of the features I would like:

* Very low barrier to entry. We want to make it as easy as possible for anyone to capture any cool little snippet of code. On [holoviews-contrib](https://github.com/ioam/holoviews-contrib)  the idea was to use the GitHub wiki for this purpose.
* A route for a rough example to gradually transform into something polished to use in the official docs or on the website.
* A way for people to just submit *ideas* for simple example that are meaningful or illustrative. Good examples use minimal dependencies and don't need much code.
* A way to add/suggest new datasets. We can add small examples directly to the holoviews repo (say) but we can also add bigger examples on S3 which we can fetch via intake.

## Possible Approaches

* A new GitHub repo on the `pyviz-topics` organization called contrib. This would be a second attempt at [holoviews-contrib](https://github.com/ioam/holoviews-contrib) broadened to all of pyviz. We would have to think about how we could make such a repo more successful this time around.
* A common/shared anaconda.org account where people can upload anaconda projects or notebooks. Can you have such an account that anyone can push to?
* GitHub gists?
* A simple web interface where people could upload stuff into our public S3 bucket?

My general feeling is that our users have plenty of interesting ideas that should be more widely disseminated and that we could use to avoid the pain of trying to come up with new examples from scratch over and over again.

Lastly, I feel that even if such a resource were only used by the pyviz devs without much user adoption, this would be an improvement over the current situation.

items.title: Can I pay for professional support?
items.body: I love pyviz and it looks great. However, sometimes I still can't figure out all the details to get what I want, and I want to pay money to save time because I'm not good at programming. Will Anaconda provide such service? Thanks!

import holoviews as hv, geoviews as gv, param, dask.dataframe as dd, cartopy.crs as crs
import panel as pn

from colorcet import cm
from holoviews.operation.datashader import rasterize, shade
from holoviews.streams import RangeXY


hv.extension('bokeh', logo=False)

usecols = ['dropoff_x','dropoff_y','pickup_x','pickup_y','dropoff_hour','pickup_hour','passenger_count']

opts = dict(width=1000,height=600,xaxis=None,yaxis=None,bgcolor='black',show_grid=False)

class NYCTaxiExplorer(param.Parameterized):
    alpha      = param.Magnitude(default=0.75, doc="Alpha value for the map opacity")
    cmap       = param.ObjectSelector(cm['fire'], objects={c:cm[c] for c in cmaps})

    @param.depends('location', 'hour')

        if self.hour != (0, 24): points = points.select(dropoff_hour=self.hour)
        return points

    @param.depends('alpha')

        return gv.tile_sources.StamenTerrain.options(alpha=self.alpha, **opts)

    def view(self,**kwargs):
        points = hv.DynamicMap(self.points)
        agg = rasterize(points, x_sampling=1, y_sampling=1, width=600, height=400)

        tiles = hv.DynamicMap(self.tiles)
        return tiles * shade(agg, streams=[stream])

r = pn.Row(taxi, taxi.view()).servable()
r.server_doc()

items.title: 01 Workflow Introduction  code does not run as bokeh server app
items.body:
I am trying to build a quick visualization with some widgets generated by panel/param to allow some interactivity. It works fine in a Jupyter Notebook but when I convert to a script for bokeh server it fails after the first interaction with this error message that ends this way:

`ValueError: Figure(id='0d3e11d7-1688-4256-a8b3-90aa21cf367d', ...) is not in list`


I converted the code from [01 Workflow Introduction](http://pyviz.org/tutorial/01_Workflow_Introduction.html) and I get the same error. It runs fine and allows one change to any of the widgets (Alpha, Cmap, Location) but then breaks.

```

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import holoviews as hv
import hvplot.pandas
import dask.dataframe as dd, geoviews as gv, cartopy.crs as crs
from colorcet import fire
from holoviews.operation.datashader import datashade
from geoviews.tile_sources import EsriImagery

topts = dict(width=700, height=600, bgcolor='black', xaxis=None, yaxis=None, show_grid=False)
tiles = EsriImagery.clone(crs=crs.GOOGLE_MERCATOR).options(**topts) 

dopts = dict(width=1000, height=600, x_sampling=0.5, y_sampling=0.5)
taxi  = dd.read_parquet('nyc_taxi_50k.parq').persist()
pts   = hv.Points(taxi, ['pickup_x', 'pickup_y'])


import param, panel as pn
from colorcet import palette

class NYCTaxi(param.Parameterized):
    alpha = param.Magnitude(default=0.75, doc="Map tile opacity")
    cmap = param.ObjectSelector('fire', objects=['fire','bgy','bgyw','bmy','gray','kbc'])
    location = param.ObjectSelector(default='dropoff', objects=['dropoff', 'pickup'])

    def make_view(self, **kwargs):
        pts   = hv.Points(taxi, [self.location+'_x', self.location+'_y'])
        trips = datashade(pts, cmap=palette[self.cmap], **dopts)
        return tiles.options(alpha=self.alpha) * trips

explorer = NYCTaxi(name="Taxi explorer")
pn.Row(explorer, explorer.make_view).servable()
```

items.title: Standardize on a pyviz console command
items.body:
Currently there seems to be a proliferation of console scripts, e.g for `holoviews`, `geoviews`, `panel` etc. As every pyviz project is likely to have user installable examples, this suggests that if we continue down this path, we will end up with a console script for every pyviz project which seems rather excessive to me.

As I understand it, the alternative is to use `pyct` directly but this is not really a name that means much to users (and not another name we really want to introduce them to). What people will have heard of is `pyviz` and a single console script that works across all pyviz projects seems a lot easier to justify (and a way to make sure everything is very consistent)

Instead of lots of console scripts, I would prefer something like:

```
pyviz geoviews examples
```

In this example, `pyviz` is the entry point, the next argument is the sub-command (addressing the pyviz subproject) and then what follows is a common interface between all the projects.

I see a couple of options how we could achieve this:

1) Offer a `pyviz_core` package which has very lightweight dependencies and is very easy to install. It offers the `pyviz` console script and can be made a dependency of all pyviz project (as it is small and pure Python with no problematic dependencies).

2) Rename `pyct` to `pyviz_core`.

I can also imagine it being `pyviz_cmd` if the main purpose is the common command-line interface across pyviz projects.

items.title: installation error conflict with Jupyter extensions
items.body:
I tried to follow the instructions to install the pyviz.

```
conda create -n pyvz python=3.6
source activate pyvz
```

First it gave me error with nbextension `Highlight selected word`, then I unchecked that plugin.

Now I got the following error.

Error:
```
$ sudo -H conda install -c pyviz/label/dev pyviz
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - jupyter_latex_envs
  - pyviz
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.
```

Date: Oct 2, 2018
platform: MacOS mojave

```
$ which conda
conda is a function
conda () 
{ 
    if [ "$#" -lt 1 ]; then
        $_CONDA_EXE;
    else
        \local cmd="$1";
        shift;
        case "$cmd" in 
            activate)
                _conda_activate "$@"
            ;;
            deactivate)
                _conda_deactivate "$@"
            ;;
            install | update | uninstall | remove)
                $_CONDA_EXE "$cmd" "$@" && _conda_reactivate
            ;;
            *)
                $_CONDA_EXE "$cmd" "$@"
            ;;
        esac;
    fi
}
conda is /Users/poudel/miniconda3/bin/conda
conda is /Users/poudel/miniconda2/bin/conda
                                                                                                                    [ 0s015 | Oct 02 04:00PM ]
(pyvz) 

```

## Fix
I used pip instead of conda and it fixed now. Also had to install jupyter also for that environment.
The jupyter in anoter environment was somehow causing the errors.

My *guess* (it's really a guess) is somewhere in the pyviz stack opens the app's main.py file as text, and assumes the default encoding of text files is utf-8 - which is not true (at least, as of python 3.6 on windows). (The main.py file is fine to run with python itself rather than bokeh, since in python 3.6 python source code files are assumed to be utf-8 by default.)

Need to investigate further (e.g. does it happen with latest bokeh? does the app work on other platforms?).

items.title: Running StockExplorer example in a bokeh server
items.body:
Hi, 

I am trying to run the StockExplorer example in a bokeh server but am not getting any interactivity. The plot and widgets show fine, but changes to widgets do not trigger any updates.

Source:
```python
import holoviews as hv
import pandas as pd
import panel as pp
import param
import parambokeh
from bokeh.sampledata import stocks
from bokeh.server.server import Server
from holoviews.operation.timeseries import rolling, rolling_outlier_std
from holoviews.streams import Stream

hv.notebook_extension('bokeh', mode='server')

def load_symbol(symbol, variable='adj_close', **kwargs):
    df = pd.DataFrame(getattr(stocks, symbol))
    df['date'] = df.date.astype('datetime64[ns]')
    return hv.Curve(df, ('date', 'Date'), variable)

stock_symbols = ['AAPL', 'IBM', 'FB', 'GOOG', 'MSFT']

class StockExplorer(Stream):
    rolling_window = param.Integer(default=10, bounds=(1, 365))

    symbol = param.ObjectSelector(default='AAPL', objects=stock_symbols)

    def view(self):
        stocks = hv.DynamicMap(load_symbol, kdims=[], streams=[self])

        # Apply rolling mean
        smoothed = rolling(stocks, streams=[self])

        # Find outliers
        outliers = rolling_outlier_std(stocks, streams=[self])
        return smoothed * outliers

def modify_doc(doc):
    explorer = StockExplorer()
    parambokeh.Widgets(explorer, continuous_update=True, callback=explorer.event, on_init=True, mode='server')
    panel = pp.Row(explorer, explorer.view())
    return panel.server_doc(doc=doc)


server = Server({'/': modify_doc}, port=0)
server.start()
server.show('/')
server.run_until_shutdown()
```
I have tried to adapt/combine examples from the "Creating interactive dashboards" and "Deploying a bokeh app" sections of pyviz/holoviews but am not having any luck. I may be doing something wrong on the `doc` side?

Worth noting, this works as expected in the notebook.

Am I missing something obvious?

items.title: What pyviz packages should there be?
items.body:
(I thought I already created this issue, but apparently not. If I missed a duplicate issue, or we discussed this elsewhere and I've forgotten to import the discussion here, please close or edit this issue...)

Currently we have one pyviz package, with dependencies for all the topics. We don't yet list topics, but will soon. At that point, should we have multiple packages (i.e. options), with each corresponding to a topic?

Also: we currently produce only a highly pinned conda package. That's ok, because pyviz isn't a library that's designed to be integrated into someone else's package (that's what the libraries underling pyviz are for). But a highly pinned conda package can be difficult to install, except in a dedicated environment. By which point, a "conda env create (some file env file on anaconda.org or maybe github)" command might make more sense...?

items.title: holoviz versioning/releasing
items.body:
I think my question is, how should holoviz be released? I.e. when do we make packages, and when do we update the website? Maybe:
* tag like v0.1.2: website build to holoviz.org, conda package to pyviz/label/main
* tag like v0.1.2a3: website build to https://pyviz-dev.github.io/, conda package to pyviz/label/dev
* update to master: website build to https://holoviz.github.io/holoviz-master

Is that enough to support what we want for now? Or e.g. is it necessary to be able to update the website without releasing packages? And I'm assuming we don't yet need to keep around versioned docs for pyviz (though we could).

(Maybe the pyviz-dev website and possibly even the packages could be linked somewhere from the readme. Maybe even the holoviz-master website would be a useful link to have, for developers.)

items.title: Repo structure
items.body:
Right now, the pyviz repo has a different structure than our other projects.  Standard projects put every notebook or app the user can run into `./examples`:

- ./examples/getting-started
- ./examples/user-guide
- ./examples/topics

PyViz puts things at the top level, and also publishes them at a different spot on the website:

- ./notebooks : tutorial notebooks (appears under `/tutorial' on the website)
- ./apps: tutorial apps
- ./exercises: tutorial exercises

We are planning to add `topics`  to PyViz, and in general things are easier if we make things uniform, so I propose that we put everything in `./examples` on PyViz like in the other projects:

- ./examples/tutorial/
- ./examples/tutorial/apps (maybe?)
- ./examples/tutorial/exercises (maybe?)
- ./examples/topics/

The website can then still use the same `tutorial` subdirectory as it does now, so it seems like this shouldn't affect existing links, and it makes the website map more clearly onto the repo (at least for those used to the `examples` directory idea).

Any votes for or against or for a modified proposal?

items.title: current version of poppler causes problem for fiona
items.body:
If poppler's installed, version 0.65.1 (at least) causes a problem for fiona on linux and mac (linux: https://travis-ci.org/pyviz/pyviz/jobs/383650789#L2372).

In the conda recipe I've constrained poppler to the last known compatible version (see #58).

For the environment, on the other hand, I'm not sure what to do. poppler doesn't exist for windows, but needs to be pinned for mac and linux. I don't know another solution except having a separate environment file for windows. 

It's possible the problems will resolve themselves if we wait and/or report to maintainers. Meanwhile, travis is updating the version of poppler after creating the environment.

items.title: Post-tutorial updates
items.body:
pyviz.org is in pretty good shape after preparing and polishing a series of releases yesterday that updated all the materials and the website. There are a few to-do items now that we didn't have time for or are based on having given the tutorial live yesterday:

Quick:

- [x] Fix PyViz logo in upper left of website; is being overwritten by "PyViz".  Maybe replace with wordmark instead of text?
- [x] Fix formatting of images in https://pyviz.github.io/pyviz/tutorial/01_Workflow_Introduction.html
- [x] Change theme colors to work with logo
- [x] Make the paragraph symbol on intrapage links much lighter gray to make it nearly invisible
- [x] Mention `conda update conda ; conda update conda` in the installation instructions (if an older conda was on their systems, installation was failing to find packages from the main channel, possibly the noarch ones)
- [x] Add big copy of logo to front page
- [x] Add project logos and some viz to the pyviz.org front page
- [x] Add link to osm-1billion example (and mention how to download the data)
- [x] Replace .opts with .options in examples
- [x] Update holoviews, geoviews, param, parambokeh, and the corresponding HoloViews version number in 00_Setup.ipynb.
- [ ] Merge in content from the PyData Cookbook
- [x] Fix [nbsite#59](https://github.com/pyviz/nbsite/issues/59) (broken links for downloading notebooks, e.g. the one on http://pyviz.org/tutorial/11_Streaming_Data.html)
- [x] Add links from each tutorial notebook on to the next
- [x] Fix non-mpl options in 02 (again!)
- [x] Fix data download path


Medium:

- [x] Do `bokeh.sampledata.download()` in the doc build in Travis to avoid having 00 Welcome fill up with [downloading messages](https://pyviz.github.io/pyviz/tutorial/00_Welcome.html)
- [x] Move paragraphs of text 00 Welcome into index.html, leaving just the mechanical bits as part of the first tutorial.
- [ ] Simplify the 01 Workflow notebook; lots of good material, but needs to be quicker
- [ ] Pin any dependencies that could conceivably vary? (#25)
- [ ] Make pyviz tests cover installing as a package and other new functionality (#81)
- [ ] Add reference data for notebooks
- [ ] Add a colorcet logo
- [ ] Add a section with links to other pyviz projects (nbsite, nbval, nbsmoke, autover, etc.)
- [ ] Add twitter feed listening to multiple projects
- [ ] Change 08_Custom_Interactivity.ipynb to use new RangeSelect tool
- [ ] Reduce overlap between tutorial sections

Long-term:

- [ ] Should fold in tutorial A1's material somewhere; it's odd to have it in an appendix.  It made sense when the tutorial was smaller, but now that there is always more material than can be covered, it's confusing to have it separate, so that the other material can't tell whether these concepts have been introduced.
- [ ] Need automated scripts for making at least the first pass at the site logo and favicon bitmaps from a transparent SVG source; currently edited those by hand for pyviz.org and other project sites have non-transparent logos. (See https://github.com/pyviz/nbsite/issues/40)
- [ ] Make sure everything is pip-installable as well as conda-installable (#81)
- [ ] Move topics from datashader and holoviews sites into pyviz, as most combine multiple tools.

items.title: Error installing examples
items.body:

When I execute the following command

`pyviz --install-examples pyviz-tutorial`

I get this error

Download complete. Extracting

items.title: Tutorial refers to notebook "Exploration with containers" that doesn't exist
items.body:
I'm going through the tutorial, which is very well done.  Kudos!

In notebooks ``03_Customizing_Visual_Appearance.ipynb`` and ``08_Custom_Interactivity.ipynb`` there are references to the notebook "exploring with containers" ``04-exploration-with-containers.ipynb`` .  But that notebook doesn't exist.

A related issue, which is more pedagogical, is that in the notebook ``08_Custom_Interactivity.ipynb``, there is the statement:

> In the exploring with containers section, the DynamicMap container was introduced. In that section, the arguments to the callable returning elements were supplied by HoloViews sliders

The issue is that the DynamicMap container really hasn't been introduced in any prior notebooks (beyond an example in notebook 1), making notebook 8 a little harder to understand.

Hope this helps improve the tutorial.

items.title: Pin more dependencies
items.body: The daily build passes and fails as dependencies move around underneath us. We should pin more dependencies, and update on something more like a monthly schedule. (We could still have a build using the latest versions of things, so we know what issues are coming.)

items.title: Make conda (meta)package
items.body:
Providing the following things?

* known-good set of dependencies (like environment.yml, but for people without the repo)
* command to download sample data
* command to install examples
* ...?

items.title: Run osx tests on master only
items.body: Because they are slow

items.title: Allow GUI tests
items.body:
Travis/linux and appveyor support GUI tests (e.g. xvfb on linux). 

I've done it before on travis/linux, but haven't tried on appveyor. I don't know about osx.

items.title: Soil physical / chemical / type data visualization example
items.body: This is a reminder for me to make a `holoviews`  example based on [these soil classification / physical data from the NASA/NOAA NLDAS project](https://ldas.gsfc.nasa.gov/nldas/NLDASsoils.php).  I have a script that downloads the data and [gets it into a single `xarray_filters.MLDataset` here](https://github.com/ContinuumIO/Elm-Earthio-NLDAS/blob/post-elm-pr-192/read_nldas_soils.py#L217) so it's pretty much a one liner if someone is looking for easy-to-get-and-use example data.  cc @gbrener

items.title: Can't use fastparquet on windows
items.body: See https://github.com/dask/fastparquet/issues/219

items.title: Only recommend and test python 3.6?
items.body: I've been supporting multiple versions of python since 2005; I can't see how I've ever benefitted from that ;)
